GLOSSARY 
 
Climate  –  The process of human and natural systems adjusting to the actual 
adaptation   or expected climate and its effects, in order to moderate harm or 
exploit  beneficial  opportunities.  Intergovernmental  Panel  on

Resilience  –  The ability of a system and its component parts to anticipate, 
absorb, accommodate, or recover from the effects of a hazardous 
event in a timely and efficient manner, including through ensuring 
the preservation, restoration, or improvement of its essential basic 
structures  and  functions.  Intergovernmental  Panel  on  Climate

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support selected developing 
member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)—Armenia, Indonesia, and 
Mongolia—to strengthen (i) country systems for climate risk-informed fiscal decision-making, and 
(ii) knowledge on climate risk-informed decision-making. 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the climate priorities of the DMCs, as reflected in their respective 
Nationally Determined Contributions, and with ADB country partnership strategies.1 The TA will 
support the implementation of the operational plan for ADB Strategy 2030 operational priority 3 
on tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental 
sustainability.2 The TA will also contribute to operational priority 2 on accelerating progress in 
gender  equality,  and  operational  priority  6  on  strengthening  governance  and  institutional 
capacity.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Developing countries in Asia and the Pacific are highly exposed to climate risk, and this 
can have a significant effect on their development strategies and investments. It is estimated that 
without timely climate action, the gross domestic product of the Asia and the Pacific region could 
decrease by as much as 3.3% by 2050 and 10.0% by 2100.4 
 
4.  Increases in temperature and changes in rainfall patterns because of climate change can 
alter economic activities in the DMCs supported under this TA, especially in sectors that are highly 
sensitive to climatic conditions, with implications for revenue and wider inclusive economic 
growth. Additionally, increases in the intensity and frequency of extreme weather events can 
burden governments’ fiscal positions because of the cost of response and recovery. With rapid 
increases in climate risk, it is expected that the costs of dealing with these impacts will increase 
in the future and severely strain the fiscal position of the DMCs. The key factors that determine 
an economy’s fiscal vulnerability to the potential impact of climate change include the degree of 
exposure to hazards, the level of protection in place, and the state’s liability for damages incurred; 
these factors need to be addressed in the context of changing climate risk.5 
 
5.  Further, recognizing that the economies of the DMCs supported under this TA are largely 
dependent on the climate-sensitive sectors of agriculture, tourism, and fisheries, it is critical to 
understand the long-term climate-related risks and opportunities in these sectors, informed by 
gender analysis, and to develop climate-resilient pathways. These pathways can help articulate 
the  sector’s  long-term  vision  and  guide  the  identification  and  prioritization  of  policies  and

investments—public and private—that can help achieve the vision by addressing risks, exploring 
opportunities, and maximizing benefits. Such an approach would ensure that investments do not 
lock  in  economies  to  maladaptive  pathways.  Climate-resilient  pathways  can  also  help 
development partners, such as ADB, to prioritize their support in specific sectors through policy, 
investments, and knowledge. 
 
6.  To address the impacts of climate risk on fiscal sustainability, DMCs supported under this 
TA  need  to  urgently  integrate  climate  resilience  considerations  in  fiscal  decision-making 
processes to (i) inform the appropriate level of spending on climate adaptation actions and (ii) 
determine potential sources of revenue (such as through environmental taxes) to finance climate 
adaptation measures. Such integration will allow DMCs to (i) identify, prioritize, and implement 
climate  adaptation  strategies,  including  public  investments  in  resilient  infrastructure  and 
livelihoods that promote inclusive economic development; (ii) adopt regulations that steer public 
and private development in a resilient direction; (iii) introduce fees and taxes on the use of natural 
resources that will be affected by changes in climate variables; and (iv) formulate incentives to 
encourage households and the private sector to invest in resilience building. The urgency in 
undertaking such integration is critical because the effects of climate change are not increasing 
at a linear rate, and beyond a certain threshold the correlation between changes in each climate 
variable (such as temperature increase) and its impact on the economy (such as agricultural 
productivity) becomes intensely negative and thereby reduces opportunities for adaptation. 
 
7.  The need to integrate climate resilience considerations into fiscal decision-making is more 
apparent in the current context of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) recovery, as the pandemic 
has highlighted the underlying drivers of vulnerability and emphasized the importance of building 
resilience to shocks.6 As countries design their recovery packages, potentially including reforms, 
tax cuts, subsidies, and incentives, it will be important to understand the implication of potential 
recovery measures on climate-resilient development, identify trade-offs (especially in the context 
of addressing multi-hazard considerations), and promote green and resilient recovery measures. 
 
8.  Globally,  the  importance  of  climate  risk-informed  fiscal  decision-making  is  gaining 
momentum. The Global Commission on Adaptation (GCA) has highlighted the importance of 
integrating climate risk into all aspects of planning and decision-making.7 The Coalition of Finance 
Ministers for Climate Action, which brings together fiscal and economic policy makers from more 
than 50 countries (including Indonesia) in leading the global climate response, has adopted the 
Helsinki Principles, which promote integration of climate considerations in macroeconomic policy, 
fiscal planning, budgeting, public investment management, and procurement practices.8 The 
Group of 20 “Principles of Quality Infrastructure Investment” include a principle on building 
resilience to disasters and other risks. 
 
9.  Despite increasing awareness of climate risk and its potential adverse impact on long-
term development, the DMCs supported under this TA are at an early stage of integrating climate 
resilience considerations into fiscal decision-making, and they require support in overcoming 
challenges related to (i) limited availability of information and tools that can inform country 
systems, and (ii) limited access to knowledge and global good practices. This was confirmed by

10.  Challenges related to information and tools include (i) limited availability of climate risk 
information that can be used for fiscal decision-making purposes; (ii) limited awareness on how 
to integrate climate resilience considerations into macroeconomic forecasting and public financial 
management tools; (iii) limited capacity to incorporate uncertainty in decision-making; (iv) limited 
mechanisms for interministerial and interagency cooperation to discuss risks and opportunities 
faced by key economic sectors and how such understanding can guide the development of 
climate-resilient pathways; and (iv) limited opportunities for stakeholder coordination among 
government,  the  private  sector  and  civil  society  organizations  to  prioritize  and  mobilize 
investments for climate adaptation. In regard to limited knowledge, recognizing that the integration 
of climate resilience considerations in fiscal decision-making is a relatively new topic for the DMCs 
supported through this TA, it is important to facilitate access to lessons emerging from similar 
global and regional initiatives, and to ensure there are opportunities for the DMCs to learn from 
their peers in other countries. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: climate risk considerations integrated into 
macro-fiscal and public financial management processes. The TA will have the following outcome: 
decision-making for climate-resilient development in selected  DMCs  improved.9 The  outcome 
indicator will be as follows: three DMCs have integrated climate resilience considerations in 
selected fiscal policy and management processes. This will be measured by the tools developed 
through the TA used (i) in implementing national climate adaptation plans in the three DMCs, and 
(ii) in informing at least three policies. Recognizing the differences in the nature of climate risks 
and in the fiscal policy and management processes in each of the three DMCs, the proposed 
outcome indicator will allow achieving the outcome within the context of respective national 
priorities. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output  1:  Country  systems  for  climate  risk-informed  fiscal  decision-making 
strengthened. Under this output, the TA will support the following:  
(i)  Diagnostic  work  to  provide  recommendations  for  mainstreaming  climate 
resilience  considerations  into  macroeconomic  policy,  medium-term  fiscal 
strategies, annual budget strategy papers, public investment management, 
and public procurement processes. The recommendations will focus on tools 
for  considering  climate  impact  in  macroeconomic  forecasting  and  fiscal 
planning,  to  inform  (a)  expenditure  and  revenue  (such  as  through 
environmental  taxes)  for  climate  adaptation,  (b)  guidance  on  integrating 
climate risk considerations into budgeting and procurement processes, and (c) 
macroeconomic and fiscal assessments, based on country priorities.10 
 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
10 The exact nature of these activities will differ in each DMC and will be decided during the inception phase. This will 
build on the work carried out by the United Nations Development Programme to support countries in undertaking 
their climate public expenditure and institutional reviews to inform budget for climate actions.

4   
 
(ii)  Development of a climate-resilient pathway for a selected sector in each of 
three DMCs supported under the TA, which will help articulate a long-term 
vision and guide the identification and prioritization of strategies, policies, and 
investments to achieve such a vision. Identification of such investments would 
also provide guidance to ADB in developing a pipeline of projects in the 
selected sector. This sector will be selected in consultation with the DMCs 
considering national priorities, including sectors identified in their Nationally 
Determined Contributions, national adaptation plans, and COVID-19 recovery 
plans.11 The climate-resilient pathways will be informed by gender analysis.12 
(iii)  Capacity building of staff from relevant DMC ministries, including staff from 
ministries of finance, ministries of planning, and selected sector ministries, on 
the use of (a) climate risk information and other hazard information (along with 
uncertainties in fiscal decision-making) and (b) risk-informed planning tools 
and guidelines. The capacity building will be carried out in person. Possible 
partnerships with national training institutions and/or academic institutions will 
be explored to build a cohort of trainers. 
(iv)  Strengthening  national  interagency  coordination  mechanisms  on  climate 
adaptation through regular meetings and dialogue to facilitate climate risk-
informed fiscal decision-making.13 
 
13.  Support provided through proposed diagnostic work, improved understanding of long-term 
climate risk and opportunities in specific sectors, capacity building on use of climate risk-informed 
fiscal planning tools and guidelines, and strengthened coordination between ministries and with 
stakeholders,  will  lead  to  improved  decision-making  for  climate-resilient  development  and 
development and strengthening of fiscal policy and management processes to support such 
decision-making. The proposed scope of the output is in line with the findings from global 
research, as documented in the GCA’s flagship report calling for leadership on climate resilience 
(footnote 7). The GCA report calls for a revolution in the understanding of climate risk and 
reflection on such understanding in planning and finance-related decision-making.14 In particular, 
the GCA report highlights the need for upstream macroeconomic analysis of climate risk, taking 
a longer-term perspective in sector planning that factors in uncertainty, and integrating resilience 
considerations into investment and financing decisions from the beginning. Operationalizing such 
directions requires improved in-country systems for climate risk-informed fiscal decision-making. 
 
14.  Output 2: Knowledge on climate risk-informed decision-making enhanced. Under 
this output, the TA will support the following: 
(i)  Facilitating roundtable dialogue between national and local governments, civil 
society organizations, and the private sector on the importance of investing in 
climate resilience. Such dialogue will help raise ambitions for investing in 
climate  adaptation,  identify  challenges  faced  by  different  stakeholders 
(including the private sector), and discuss opportunities for investing in climate

adaptation by adopting a whole-of-society approach toward building climate 
resilience. 
(ii)  Conducting regional learning workshops with TA DMCs and other selected 
DMCs  to  share  experiences  on  climate  risk-informed  fiscal  management 
processes. 
(iii)  Organizing online and/or in-person peer-to-peer sharing of experiences of TA 
DMCs  with  other  DMCs,  especially  with  DMCs  that  implemented  similar 
initiatives under the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience (PPCR) under the 
Climate Investment Funds, which ADB and other multilateral development 
banks are implementing entities.15 
(iv)  Sharing experiences by TA DMCs globally through the GCA’s capacity building 
program for central ministries of finance and planning to support their efforts to 
integrate climate risks into decision-making processes.16 
 
15.  The GCA calls for collaboration from various segments of society—government, the 
private sector, and civil society organizations—to collectively take forward the agenda on climate 
resilience. The multi-stakeholder roundtable dialogues proposed by the GCA aim to promote a 
whole-of-society  approach  in  understanding  risk,  identifying  opportunities,  and  prioritizing 
investments,  thereby  improving  climate  resilience  decision-making.  Further,  the  proposed 
approach for sharing experiences within each country, with other countries in the same region, 
and globally is line with the priorities of the Coalition of Finance Ministers for Climate Action, which 
has recognized sharing experiences as one of the six principles of the Helsinki Principles, as this 
sharing provides mutual encouragement and promotes collective understanding of policies and 
practices  for  climate  action.  A  peer-to-peer  learning  format—online  and  in-person—will  be 
adopted to facilitate sharing of experiences. 
 
16.  The TA is innovative, as it attempts to shift the entry point for climate adaptation from a 
project  level  to  upstream  fiscal  and  sector  planning.  Such  an  approach  will  allow  for  the 
identification of wider processes that can help influence the future pipeline of investments in 
climate adaptation, including investments that could be potentially be financed by ADB. Further, 
by promoting a whole-of-society approach toward resilience, the TA aims to systematically 
engage  the  private  sector  in  climate  adaptation-related  investments,  which  is  critical  in 
recognizing the scale of finance needed for climate adaptation.17 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,150,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Strategic Climate Fund18 and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB will administer the TA. The Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Division 
of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will lead the implementation of 
the TA activities in partnership with the East Asia Department, Central and West Asia Department, 
Southeast Asia Department, and Governance Thematic Group. The Climate Change and Disaster 
Risk Management Division will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and will organize 
national and regional workshops and seminars. Where relevant, the three regional departments 
will provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. Government concurrence will be 
sought prior to implementation of activities in the DMCs.20

climate risks and handling uncertainty to subnational government officials. As the co-secretariat 
of the GCA, WRI is leading its global initiative on mainstreaming climate resilience, which is very

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,150,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Strategic Climate Fund for Improved Decision-
Making for Climate-Resilient Development in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.
